quoteFirst: The Battle Cruisers steamed some 64 miles between
quoteLast: , the time of opening fire, and 6.17 P.M. the time that the Battle Fleet commenced action, and a further distance of some 57 miles to 9 P.M., when the Fleet turned to the southward for the night. The Battle Fleet steamed some 47 miles between the commencement of their engagement with the High Sea Fleet and the turn to the southward at 9 P.M.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: The hours from ten to twelve he devotes to the compilation of his Memoirs in fifty-four volumes. A limited edition of large-paper copies is to be issued. From
quoteLast: he reviews regiments, cashiers colonels, captures fortresses, carries his own dispatches to himself, and makes speeches of varying length to all who will listen to him. Any professional reporter found taking accurate notes of His Majesty's words is immediately blown from a Krupp gun with the new smokeless powder.
title: Mr. Punch's History of Modern England, Vol. 3 (of 4).—1874-1892
author: Graves, Charles L. (Charles Larcom), 1856-1944

quoteFirst: ; and in the afternoon the watch that had but “four hours out” the night before have the afternoon watch below, from
quoteLast: The time from 4 to 8 P.M. is divided into two short watches, called “dog-watches,” for the purpose of regulating or keeping them in proper succession. For instance: the larboard watch is on deck from 8 P.M. to 12; the starboard from 12 to 4 A.M.; the larboard from 4 to 8 A.M.; the starboard from 8 A.M. to 12 M.; the larboard from 12 to 4 P.M.; the starboard from 4 to 6 P.M., and the larboard from 6 to 8 P.M., when the watch is set. They are thus changed every night, one having eight hours on deck and four below one night, and the next _vice versa_, continuing thus for the voyage.
title: Life and Adventure in the South Pacific
author: Jones, John D.

quoteFirst: At that time they are again changed, the watch that had “eight hours out” having the “forenoon watch below,” from 8 till 12 M.; and in the afternoon the watch that had but “four hours out” the night before have the afternoon watch below, from
quoteLast: The time from 4 to 8 P.M. is divided into two short watches, called “dog-watches,” for the purpose of regulating or keeping them in proper succession. For instance: the larboard watch is on deck from 8 P.M. to 12; the starboard from 12 to 4 A.M.; the larboard from 4 to 8 A.M.; the starboard from 8 A.M. to 12 M.; the larboard from 12 to 4 P.M.; the starboard from 4 to 6 P.M., and the larboard from 6 to 8 P.M., when the watch is set.
title: Life and Adventure in the South Pacific
author: Jones, John D.

title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: At
quoteLast: the action between the battle cruisers began at a range of about 18,500 yards, fire being opened by the two forces practically simultaneously. At the commencement the fire from the German vessels was rapid and accurate, the _Lion_ being hit twice three minutes after fire was opened, and the _Lion_, _Tiger_ and _Princess Royal_ all receiving several hits by 4 P.M.; observers on board our own ships were also of opinion that our fire was effective at that stage.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: "But not insurmountable," replied the lawyer. "Dr. Whipple happens to be the most methodical of men. 'At
quoteLast: , on Saturday, June 28, I took Mr. Harry Arnold's pulse in his own room at Woodlawn,' said he, consulting his notes. 'It was eighty-three beats to the minute.
title: The Incendiary: A Story of Mystery
author: Leahy, William Augustine, 1867-

quoteFirst: His course was east-southeast, and he was converging on that of the enemy, who was steering rather more directly south. By the time the line was formed the range was about 23,000 yards, and at
quoteLast: had been closed to 18,500, when both sides opened fire simultaneously. When the range had closed to about 14,000 yards or less, parallel courses were steered and kept until the end of this phase of the engagement.
title: The British Navy in Battle
author: Pollen, Arthur Joseph Hungerford, 1866-1937

quoteFirst: Mosquitoes abound in Manila, coming from the numerous malarious creeks which traverse the wards, and few persons can sleep without a curtain. To be at one's ease, a daily bath is indispensable. The heat from
quoteLast: is oppressive from March to May, and most persons who have no afternoon occupation, sleep the _siesta_ from 1 to 3 o'clock. The conventional lunch-hour all over the Colony is noon precisely, and dinner at about 8 o'clock.
title:
The Philippine Islands
A Political, Geographical, Ethnographical, Social and Commercial History of the Philippine Archipelago, Embracing the Whole Period of Spanish Rule
author: Foreman, John, F.R.G.S.

quoteFirst: "I don't know just when it did arrive, for I didn't look at my watch then, but it left at
quoteLast: . I was getting mighty sleepy, but I determined to see how long it would stay in one place, for it costs money to hire a car by the hour--even one of those Green-and-White taxis."
